clinical_study.brief_title: Adaptive Treatment De-escalation in Favorable Risk HPV-Positive Oropharyngeal Carcinoma
clinical_study.official_title: Adaptive Treatment De-escalation in Favorable Risk HPV-Positive Oropharyngeal Carcinoma

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: This will be a phase II single-arm clinical trial. The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of deescalating chemoradiation treatment based onmid-treatment tumor response. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate progression-free survival at 2 years.

detailed_description.textblock: The secondary objectives will include 2-year loco-regional control and overall survival, quality of life, and late toxicity. Quality of life outcomes can be assessed with a validated, self-reported questionnaire. Late toxicity can be assessed using the National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events. Additionally, the prognostic value of positive HPV in salivary rinse as well as plasma at mid and post- treatment time points will be evaluated with a baseline evaluation pre-treatment. Radiomic analysis of pre-treatment imaging will be correlated with outcomes.

primary_outcome.description: The rate of progression-free survival will be estimated using time to failure methods; Kaplan Meier curves will be provided and the rate at 2 years will be estimated using a 95% confidence interval. Patients who do not experience progression of disease and have not died will be censored on the date of last follow up.

clinical_study.condition: HPV Positive Oropharyngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma

intervention.description: An interval scan at 4 weeks to assess for a good response defined as >40% nodal shrinkage will stratify patients into receiving standard treatment (≤40% nodal shrinkage) or a dose-deescalated treatment regimen (>40% nodal shrinkage).

Intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) is an advanced type of radiation therapy used to treat cancer and noncancerous tumors. IMRT uses advanced technology to manipulate photon and proton beams of radiation to conform to the shape of a tumor. Patients will be treated with intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) with megavoltage photons
